body: This is awesome! I'll pull your branch in again and see what I can do.

Ok this PR is now based off of your current branch, I'm keeping an eye on travis. I'm hoping to find time and take on the selective test part and setting up an initial db.

It looked like deleting the cache can be done manually in the Travis-UI, I think this may be sufficient.

You might have pulled my branch just at the minute it is not working :-). If you did, I'll fix it tomorrow. I have probably a better way of using the wheels anyway. 

Sent from my iPhone

@mistercrunch branch is done. It now fully caches python dependencies after first build. First build can take around 30min, but subsequent builds only around 3min. Further optimization can be done by adding the hadoop downloads to the cache or, only for now, commenting them out as they are not used yet.

I have also included python 3.5 to the build matrix as I saw that was a request somewhere. It fails on the wheel now at the moment as librrabitmq is in the requirements and that is not python 3 compatible yet. Maybe differ between different python versions for the requirements? Anyways its means that 4 builds are now triggered.

It would be nice if airflow pre-fills its connections for testing. In travis you can use mysql (username root password blank or username travis password blank) and postgres (user: postgres). Both have been pre-configured with a "airflow" database that is empty.
See http://docs.travis-ci.com/user/database-setup/ for more details.

Enjoy fixing the tests ;-)!
- Some issues that might popup: in tox.ini you can specify "deps=-rrequirements.txt" but this didn't do anything for me, so I used the commands. Seems to work fine.
[tableExists](https://hive.apache.org/javadocs/r0.13.1/api/metastore/org/apache/hadoop/hive/metastore/HiveMetaStoreClient.html#tableExists%28java.lang.String, java.lang.String%29)

It works for me by changing the DAG `start_date` to `datetime.now() - schedule_interval`. No weird time sensor needed. :P 

Also I think it will be handy by adding some logging infos in class method `is_queueable()` of `airflow.models.TaskInstance` class:

```
def is_queueable(self, flag_upstream_failed=False):
        logging.debug('Task Instance is queueable check!')
        if self.execution_date > datetime.now() - self.task.schedule_interval:
            logging.debug('Too early to execute: execution_date {0} + task.schedule_interval {1} > datetime.now() {2}'.format(self.execution_date, self.task.schedule_interval, datetime.now()))
            return False
            ....
```
I'm not sure what's causing the merge conflict -- I think it's from the last commit (`requirements.txt`, `setup.py`), but I can't tell.

the -s of the `airflow run` command is used internally to bypass the depends_on_past criteria on the start_date of the backfill. Meaning if your task has a `start_date` that on `2015-01-01`, but your backfill start_date is `2015-02-01`, it will disregard `depends_on_paste=True` for `2015-02-01`. It has no other effect. The `execution_date` param is the one that is matters and is the 3rd arg after `airflow run`.

@mistercrunch I have update my branch again and fixed a couple of things:
- Copying the airflow_travis.cfg also in my environment :-)
- Instead of using pymysql I am suggesting to use mysqlclient which is the updated MySQL-Python, but with python3 support and actively maintained. It's a drop in replacement

Now integration tests with mysql pass and no errors on sqlalchemy anymore.
Btw I also suggest going down to python 3.4 as a target. Many libs are not at 3.5 making us tracking down a lot of those issues (ie. mysqlclient goes up to 3.4)

@jlowin It looks like Airflow does not add AIRFLOW_HOME to the path, which explains why I also can't get my airflow_login module imported.

@mistercrunch Are there specific reasons for not adding AIRFLOW_HOME to the path? If i add `sys.path.append(conf.get('core', 'airflow_home'))` to the root `__init__.py` that seems to work fine (and more convenient than prefixing every command with PYTHONPATH=...etc).
@bolkedebruin probably right about 3.4. Got over eager...

Oh! That makes sense to me. Thank you so much @mistercrunch

I believe I should use task `execution_time` instead of task `start_time` as the reference of time in my operator. And I will try to get the `execution_time` of `TaskInstance` in my operator.

Just realize `execute()` function of operator takes `context` as an argument. I can get `execution_date` from it. Very very handy.

Great work! Thanks a lot!

Adding your package's root to the PYTHONPATH is a bad idea. Most packages have common module names like utils, models, app or settings. If you have multiple applications adding their root to the PYTHONPATH there's no namespacing and good luck understanding what `import settings` is actually doing. 

What you want is your app to be namespaced in the PYTHONPATH so that you can `from airflow import settings`

Note that messing with `sys.path` is somewhat hacky or magical and it can interfere with users assumptions. Taking a certain codepath that modifies `sys.path` may result in different behavior in your imports, which can be tricky to debug.

I've been thinking about how it'd be nice to have a `SqlAlchemyHook` to write cross db code through their expression language.

But it should be easy to write a `DbApiHook.get_sqla_engine()`. The prefix for the URI (the "mysql" in `mysql://root@localhost`) should probably be a class level param of the derivatives of `DbApiHook`. Then it's just a matter of putting together the URI from the connection object.
You couldn't get the password through the connection object could you though?
@jackgolding believe that was fixed in #445 (see https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/airflow/hooks/dbapi_hook.py#l44) -- you may need to update your airflow to see the change!

Something important to keep in mind: SqlAlchemy URI strings are always passed to the engine as plain text (whether they come from Airflow or any other library). In addition, the password can be viewed (in plain text) in SqlAlchemy at any time, if you know where to look. So while you may use different strategies to securely transmit the password to the machine on which SqlAlchemy is running, once there it becomes potentially visible to anyone with permission to run code in the same environment.

@mistercrunch unit testing the authentication mechanisms requires (I think!) to refactor app.py so it creates the app in a function, eg see http://flask.pocoo.org/snippets/20/ , to be able to pass a different configuration to the app per test. 

This looks like a good idea but also as a major undertaking. If you have a better idea how to unit test the functionality please advice. If refactoring is unavoidable (and it seems more future proof anyway), I will need some help.

The connection object knows how to decrypt password.

@mistercrunch if we don't want to store logs in S3, maybe we could explore using the existing `Log` class (https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/airflow/models.py#L1210) to store logs in the AirflowDB? The DB is the only stateful part of airflow by design; the assumption that workers (and their filesystems) are always available is a weak one.

It'd be nice to get more visibility on progress outside of the log. In some cases a job is unaware of which percentage it is at, but is aware of state or progress. For instance a task may know it has moved 20000 rows so far, without knowing how many more there are coming. 

Maybe there could be a field in the task_instance table for progress and could be used differently by different operators as a short string. Data transfer operators could post how many rows they've moved so far. Hive jobs could post which statement/phase/percentage they're at, ... 

The API is easy to implement (add a `BaseOperator.set_progress()`), the hard part is to adapt the operators to periodically adjust their progress in a meaningful way.
Nice. Very useful indeed!

Somehow this PR fell into a crack, I didn't realize it was here. I actually think we may want to use this at Airbnb.

Now that I'm reviewing it it seems like a straightforward way to do this, but can the log be seen while the task is running?

@mistercrunch not as structured right now (the logs are shipped to S3 only when the run is finished). That was simply because I was trying to implement this as quickly and least-intrusively as possible. But we can definitely work something out.

Here are some thoughts:
1. Have `Executor` ship logs of any running tasks to S3 whenever `heartbeat()` is called.  The only issue I see is that it looks like running a task locally uses `LocalTaskJob` but not `LocalExecutor` -- or any executor for that matter (https://github.com/jlowin/airflow/blob/s3_log/airflow/jobs.py#L744). But an extra line of code in LocalTaskJob could solve that.
2. If the task state is `RUNNING`, serve logs from the worker. Otherwise, get them from S3. Less excited about this one because it doesn't solve the problem for users who can't access the logs.
@mistercrunch is this something that we would like to have? I wouldn't mind taking a stab at this when I have time.

Yes please do! This slider might work pretty well:
http://seiyria.com/bootstrap-slider/

I don't think I like option 1 as workers can have many slots (we have 192 slots on some workers) and that shipping the entire log to s3 every 30 seconds or minute (reasonable heartbeat) for all ongoing tasks is significant workload... Or maybe not doing it at every heartbeat?

We've had many discussions internally on how to do this right, and the clean ones include some subsystem like kafka or fluentd, but we can't make assumptions for the community so we'd have to write an interface which makes it harder.

This might be hacky, but what about pushing to s3 on demand? The challenge is to do all this in the scope of a web request: passing a message, picking it up, uploading to s3, passing a message back that says "done", rendering the page from s3... Celery doesn't allow to target a specific worker, so that doesn't work, and the heartbeat mechanism may be a little slow to do this interactively.  

Distributed systems are hard.

At some point I was fed up and said something like "I swear to god I'm going to setup a mount point for the logs" and everyone seemed to think it was the absolute worst idea. So I wrote the integration with the static web server that we're using today.
Ok I'll test this manually in our environment and see confirm that our plugins are working.

That makes sense. I'm going to give option 2 a shot. While tasks are running, it'll be the same behavior as it is today. Once a task completes, it sends its logs off to S3 (if the user provided an S3 log location).
Thanks! That is appreciated. The other PR (for more flexible config) is ready when this is in

@mistercrunch here's how this works now:
1. Users must define `S3_LOG_FOLDER` in airflow.cfg (the following assumes it exists and starts with `s3://`)
2. Logs are stored as they are today. However, whenever a task finishes running, its log is shipped to S3. First, we compare the log file post-run to the log file pre-run to find only the "new" log activity. Then we download any existing logs from S3 and append the new activity. Finally, the complete log is loaded to S3. This way we get around S3's lack of append functionality.
3. When a user views a log in the UI, we first check the local filesystem. Then we check for any workers serving logs (so far, no change from current behavior). If -- and only if -- neither of those results in a log, we try to load from S3. 

I think this gives a good blend of current behavior (with live logs served from workers) and a static fallback/backup in s3. Please let me know what you think.

You shouldn't have to restart anything. Though we had corner cases on the scheduler side that we solved with a shortcut at Airbnb. We fully restart the scheduler every 5 runs to make sure it 100% represents what's in the file system. Corner cases included dag_ids that had moved from a file to another, files getting deleted and the dag_id lingering, ... 

We will address these issues so that no one has to restart the scheduler, but in the meantime you may want to wrap an `airflow scheduler -n 5` (run 5 schedule cycles and exits) command into a bash script or something like runit that restarts it as soon as it's done.

No need to restart flower.

As far as the web server goes, you may need to hit the refresh button on the main page, it's the rightmost  icon on the DAGs table view. This "expires" the DAG, meaning that the webserver(s) will see that they loaded the DAG before that expiration date and reload it, assuming that it's still in the same file where it found it originally.
Seems reasonable.
Looks good. Thanks for the PR.
Thanks. I'll change it to not restart anything. But to confirm, so scheduler restart could cause T3 to not execute?

I am playing with the idea data profiling/data quality. It can happen for some reason that results of a query are different than expected. We have been bitten by this for example on a cluster upgrade when hive start behaving different and started to return more rows than it should. It would be nice if DAGs could output metrics/stats that are automatically available in a chart on the profiling page so one can monitor data quality. Ideally one can run analytics on these metrics in order to recognize issues by defining boundaries for example. 

Of course it can more or less already be done by defining a schema yourself upload it from a task in the DAG and then define it on the data profiling page. However having this available as a generic functionality in the core of airflow (storing JSON maybe?) makes it easier to do and faster.
@artwr feel free to merge if you can confirm that won't break anything on your side
Nice.
:+1:  Thanks for the PR.
@jlowin, instead of returning, I would rather raise an exception, since the result of the task should be a failure in this case, do you agree?

The test failure looks spurious. :+1:

Very nice. We'll be using this feature starting tomorrow.

At this time, you can use pytz to make conversions between timezones and make your dags work at correct time. In example, we make a datetime without timezone, then localize at our timezone, later we normalize to UTC and finally remove timezone info (because airflow don't work with tzs). It's a bit tricky but it works as well as it pass the change of daylight saving without problems.
Note: we have our system in UTC and want to make it work with special tz. Logs are showing them output in UTC, but knowing how many hours differs with UTC, we know that it works.
Thank you so much
